title: MLB DFS Plays: Friday 9/13
text:
This article will outline the best daily fantasy MLB plays of the day at every position. We will take a comprehensive look to uncover these core recommendations, factoring respective salaries into the analysis.

Please note, these player picks were organized early in the day. For MLB contests, always check lineups and weather closer to game time. Rain, wind, or unexpected managerial decisions could open up additional sources of value. Be sure to keep an eye on the MLB Headlines and Injuries desk.

Editor’s Note: Stay ahead of the competition from wire to wire with rankings, customizable projections, trade evaluator, exclusive columns and more in our Season Pass. And start using optimized lineups with our DFS Toolkit!

Scroll to continue with content Ad

We’re cooking with 13 games tonight.

PITCHER

Gerrit Cole – Houston Astros (at Royals)

Cole is clearly the top pick tonight. He’s also the most expensive player in the slate. The availability of alternative aces like Max Scherzer and Luis Castillo could help to keep Cole’s ownership at a manageable level, although I do expect him to be the most popular hurler. The Royals offense has some modest bright spots, but it’s still among the weakest in the league. Kauffman Stadium should further serve to aid Cole in his DFS point gathering.

Also Consider: Max Scherzer, Luis Castillo, Adam Wainwright (value), Tyler Beede (value), Adrian Houser (value)

CATCHER / FIRST BASE

Luke Voit – New York Yankees (at Anthony Kay)

Story continues

Voit is a double threat, offering one of the best first baseman projections and a relatively low cost. He’s visiting the Blue Jays. Their rookie starter managed to skate through his debut while mostly avoiding damage, but he’s unlikely to repeat the feat. While Kay has some long-term potential, at present he’s an unfinished product with shaky command and no reliable weapons. Let us not forget the Blue Jays terrible bullpen too. Voit has a one-in-four chance to homer. His OBP-heavy profile promises run production too.

Also Consider: Sean Murphy (value), Austin Hedges (value), Jake Rogers (value), Eric Hosmer (value), Matt Olson, Pete Alonso

SECOND BASE

Jonathan Villar – Baltimore Orioles (at Jordan Zimmermann)

Villar recently received credit for hitting the home run that broke the single-season leaguewide record. He’s hammered a career high 21 big flies despite no indication he’s actually improved as a hitter. In fact, his 27.9 percent hard contact rate is among the worst in the league. He’s a ground ball hitter who is best targeted for his potential to slap multiple hits and perhaps steal some bases. Consider combining him with other Orioles. Zimmermann rarely records strikeouts and can skew a little towards fly ball contact. Villar has a little under a one-in-five chance for a home run, although you should not pick him for potential power output. As with Voit, don’t forget there’s a bad bullpen hiding behind Zimmermann.

Also Consider: Gleyber Torres, Jose Altuve, DJ LeMahieu, Greg Garcia (value), Nick Solak (value), Josh VanMeter (value), Sheldon Neuse (value)

THIRD BASE

Matt Chapman – Oakland Athletics (at Brock Burke)

Chapman is one of the best hitters in the slate. He’s priced like a typical upper-mid-tier bat. It’s always a good idea to target Chapman against southpaws – he’s a verified lefty masher. This season, a low BABIP is hiding otherwise gaudy power numbers versus opposite-handed pitchers. As a bonus, he transforms into a fly ball hitter when with the platoon advantage. Burke is an extreme ground ball guy. The juxtaposition promises power potential for Chapman – nearly a one-in-three chance to go yard.

Also Consider: Nolan Arenado, Manny Machado, Yoan Moncada, Rio Ruiz (value)

SHORTSTOP

Trevor Story – Colorado Rockies (vs Joey Lucchesi)

You didn’t think we were going to overlook a Coors Field game, did you? Lucchesi is having a strong season, and he’s tamped down on his past issues against right-handed hitters. However, he is a ground ball pitcher while Story is a lefty-mashing fly ball hitter. He’s the top projected hitter in the slate. Not only does he have a one-in-three shot at a homer, he’s also among the most obvious plays for multiple deep shots.

Also Consider: Marcus Semien, Machado, Torres, Alex Bregman, Villar, Luis Urias (value)

OUTFIELD

Nick Martini – San Diego Padres (at Jeff Hoffman)

If we’re going to cover one side of the Coors Field, we ought to touch in on the other side. Martini is expected to bat second for the Padres. If so, he’s one of the top value plays in the slate. He’s not much of a home run threat, although there’s at least some chance for a park and juiced ball fueled home run. Instead, you’re hoping for multiple hits and plentiful run production. The Rockies home park doesn’t just boost power output. The spacious pastures aid line driver-oriented spray hitters like Martini too. Hoffman is completely hapless when pitching at home.

Aristides Aquino – Cincinnati Reds (at Mike Leake)

Ah, remember the good ol’ days when Aquino was a daily bargain? (about a month ago)…

This hulking Franmil Reyes clone is the top projected home run threat. He has a 37 percent shot at a yakker. Multiple slams are well within grasp. He’s a pull-heavy fly ball hitter who makes frequent hard contact – the perfect profile for socking dingers. Leake is a homer prone (1.82 HR/9) ground ball pitcher – an ideal matchup for Aquino. Since joining the Diamondbacks, Leake has forgotten how to miss bats.

Also Consider: Charlie Blackmon, Mark Canha (value) Aaron Judge (value), Nick Martini (value), Khris Davis (value), Josh Naylor (value), Wil Myers, Josh Rojas (value)
